Post's Title: Covid-19 drove hundreds of Africans out of Guangzhou. A generation of mixed-race children is their legacy
Post's Text: Between 2005 and 2012, Guangzhou was estimated to be home to the largest African expatriate community in Asia. By April last year, just 4,550 Africans were living in Guangzhou, according to local authorities, including students and diplomats as well as businesspeople.

Post's Title: Dr. Fauci: 'Considerable degree of normality’ by July 4
Post's Text: Dr. Anthony Fauci says he’s optimistic that towards the “end of the summer,” everyone who wants a shot will have gotten one thanks to the opening of community vaccine centers, mobile units and getting a lot more people to administer the Covid-19 vaccines. This originally aired Sunday, March 14. The clip reflects that air date.

Post's Title: Sisters say participating in vaccine trial for kids is 'super exciting'
Post's Text: “With the pandemic, a lot has felt out of my control,” said Zoe Campbell, a 15-year-old participating in the Moderna adolescent vaccine trial. “...To be a part of that process and advancing science and making the vaccine accessible for my friends, and just all kids, was super exciting.”   "I thought it would be really cool if I can be one of the people contributing to making the vaccine available for kids," her 12-year-old sister Esme added. https://cnn.it/3vNfR94

Post's Title: Analysis: No vaccines, no leadership, no end in sight. How Brazil became a global threat
Post's Text: The Covid-19 crisis in Brazil has never been worse. Nearly every Brazilian state has an ICU occupancy of 80% or higher, according to a CNN analysis of state data. As of Friday, 16 of 26 states were at or above 90%, meaning those health systems have collapsed or are at imminent risk of doing so.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: Join Miguel Marquez for a new CNN Special Report – The Human Cost of Covid – an emotional journey of loss and survival. Tonight at 9 p.m. ET

Post's Title: What will travel look like when the pandemic is over?

Post's Title: WH Covid-19 adviser says governors 'know better' than to relax restrictions
Post's Text: White House senior adviser for coronavirus Andy Slavitt suggested that American governors “know better” than to relax Covid-19 restrictions amid fears of another surge.   “I think the governors know that they’re not helping the cause, that they’re actually weighing down the cause. They may think it’s a popular thing to do. I don’t think that’s the case. I think people want to be told what the truth of the matter is. To me, a mask feels like a very small price to pay to protect people’s lives,” Slavitt said. https://cnn.it/3ddGWKk

Our correspondent Sheri Fink, herself a doctor and a former relief worker, brings a unique perspective to reporting on the crisis facing medical facilities. She embedded this week with the Brooklyn Hospital Center ER staff to witness the challenges they face. Read her full report from inside the ER: https://nyti.ms/3amI0ce

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: The U.S. economy added 1.4 million jobs last month, as people who were furloughed earlier in the pandemic were brought back to work. But the pace of hiring was far slower than in the spring, and there are still millions who are out of work. Much of the job gains came from the hiring of close to 240,000 temporary workers for the 2020 census, most of whom will be laid off when census canvassing ends later this month.  The unemployment rate fell to 8.4% percent — lower than the peak of the Great Recession. But the number of jobs in the U.S. is still 11 million jobs below its pre-pandemic level.   Read more.  https://nyti.ms/332txj2

Post's Title: Federal Judge Bars Trump Administration From Ending Census Early
Post's Text: The Trump administration can’t end the 2020 census early, a judge ruled. The ruling says the census, which was delayed for months because of the coronavirus, needs more time to get an accurate count.

Post's Title: Why the U.S. Risks Repeating 2009’s Mistakes as the Economic Rebound Slows
Post's Text: U.S. federal aid from the first six months of the coronavirus pandemic has largely dried up and hopes for a major new relief package ahead of the election are all but dead. Now, there are signs that the economic rebound is losing steam.

Post's Title: Pressure on California hospitals is still mounting fast, Newsom says.
Post's Text: Hospitals across California are filling up to dangerous levels, Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Monday. More than 10,000 Covid-19 patients are now hospitalized in the state, he said, 72% more than two weeks ago.

Post's Title: Trump administration officials passed when Pfizer offered in late summer to sell the U.S. more vaccine doses.
Post's Text: Breaking News: Trump administration officials passed when Pfizer offered in the summer to sell the U.S. more coronavirus vaccine doses, people familiar with the matter said. Now Pfizer may not be able to provide more doses to the U.S. until next June.

Post's Title: I’m Grieving for the First Time. Can I Talk About It?
Post's Text: "My aunt died from Covid complications two weeks ago. This is my first time grieving a family member, and she’s really present in my mind. I’m not sure whether or how to bring this up with acquaintances and co-workers."

Post's Title: Even in a Pandemic, Fine Jewelry Is Selling
Post's Text: You’d think a pandemic wouldn’t bode well for jewelry sales, but the exact opposite has played out as buyers compensate for lost trips and events, get engaged, or just need a pick-me-up.

Post's Title: California, besieged by the coronavirus, is ordering many residents to stay home.
Post's Text: Southern California and the San Joaquin Valley hit the I.C.U. threshold to trigger stay-at-home orders on Saturday. Together, the regions are home to more than half of California’s population.

Post's Title: ‘Existential Peril’: Mass Transit Faces Huge Service Cuts Across U.S.
Post's Text: “Existential peril”: Mass transit across the US is reeling from the pandemic, facing steep service cuts as officials plead for help from Washington.

Post's Title: For Boris Johnson, a Week to Exorcise the Demons of 2020
Post's Text: A successful coronavirus vaccine rollout in the UK could be the last chance for Boris Johnson’s government to show competence, after botching virtually every other step of its response to the pandemic. https://nyti.ms/3mQAbBK

Post's Title: The Midwest, after being consumed by the coronavirus for months, is showing signs of progress.
Post's Text: Seven states in the Midwest have seen a sustained decrease in infections over the past 14 days, offering a glimmer of hope for a region consumed by the coronavirus.

Post's Title: ‘Nobody Sees Us’: Testing-Lab Workers Strain Under Demand
Post's Text: “There is always more work to be done than the hours to do it in.”  U.S. lab workers have processed some 192 million coronavirus tests. Many are grappling with burnout, repetitive-stress injuries and an overwhelming sense of doom.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: A devastating second coronavirus wave in Europe has forced reluctant governments back into lockdowns or restrictions and inflicted new scars on ther economies. The optimism of the summer is gone, replaced with the realization that loosening precautions led to thousands of deaths just months before vaccines may arrive.  Read more. https://nyti.ms/2IbEWXq

Post's Title: Could a Blood Test Show if a Covid-19 Vaccine Works?
Post's Text: A new study in monkeys suggests that a blood test could predict the effectiveness of Covid-19 vaccines, offering a ray of hope for speeding up clinical trials.

Post's Title: U.S. employers added 245,000 jobs in November amid a coronavirus surge.
Post's Text: Breaking News: The pace of hiring in the U.S. slowed considerably in November, with only 245,000 jobs created.

Post's Title: Europe’s Deadly Second Wave: How Did It Happen Again?
Post's Text: The second wave of Europe’s coronavirus outbreak has become deadlier than the first. How did the world’s richest club of nations find itself back in the claws of the pandemic, after having wrestled back the first wave?

Post's Title: Spit in a Tube and Mail It In: A New Frontier in Covid Testing
Post's Text: At-home saliva coronavirus tests are coming to communities across the U.S. Health officials say they could be a game-changer in detecting and slowing the spread of the virus.

Post's Title: Second Wave ‘Is Right Upon Us,’ New York Mayor Warns
Post's Text: With New York City seeing sustained increases in coronavirus-related hospital admissions, case counts and the positive test rate, Mayor Bill de Blasio warned on Thursday that a second wave of the virus “unfortunately, is right upon us.” https://nyti.ms/3lF3RAe

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: Three former U.S. presidents — Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton — have said they would be willing to get a vaccine for Covid-19 publicly to help ensure public confidence in its safety. https://nyti.ms/3ogVxbC

Post's Title: As Pandemic Reveals Gaps in Safety Nets, ‘You Can’t Look Away’
Post's Text: "Since Covid hit, the amount of people in need of food has gone up," said the founder of the nonprofit Latinos Progresando. "A lot of these things were there but Covid exposed it. Nobody can deny it. You can’t look away."

Post's Title: See Coronavirus Restrictions and Mask Mandates for All 50 States
Post's Text: More than half of the counties in Mississippi are now under the state’s most restrictive coronavirus orders, including a mask mandate and stricter limits on gatherings. We're tracking virus restrictions across the U.S. Find the latest where you live here.

Post's Title: Opinion | What’s Between 30 Million Americans and an Eviction Tsunami?
Post's Text: In The New York Times Opinion Section:  "Dec. 31. That’s when the federal eviction moratorium — which has held the pandemic-related eviction tsunami at bay — expires. After that date, more than 30 million Americans are at risk of losing their homes," writes Francesca Mari.

Post's Title: C.D.C. Director Warns of High Winter Death Toll
Post's Text: The director of the CDC predicted that total deaths from Covid-19 could reach “close to 450,000” by February unless a large percentage of Americans follow precautions like mask-wearing. https://nyti.ms/3mzaghQ

Post's Title: New York’s First Vaccine Shipment Expected Dec. 15, Cuomo Says
Post's Text: If authorized by federal regulators, vaccine doses for about 170,000 New Yorkers could arrive on Dec. 15, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said. The state will prioritize people living and working in nursing homes, and then the most at-risk health care workers. https://nyti.ms/36yqLVP

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: President-elect Joe Biden introduced key members of his economic team on Tuesday as he prepares to assume the White House with the economic recovery from the pandemic slowing and millions still out of work.  Here's a look at the team. https://nyti.ms/3fYhAkC

Post's Title: Long-Term Care Residents and Health Workers Should Get Vaccine First, C.D.C. Panel Says
Post's Text: Breaking News: Long-term care residents and at-risk health care workers should be the first people in the U.S. to get coronavirus vaccines, a panel of experts advising the CDC said.

Post's Title: New At-Home Covid Test Gets Green Light From F.D.A.
Post's Text: The FDA issued an emergency authorization on Tuesday for the U.S.’s first coronavirus test that can run from start to finish at home without the need for a prescription.

Post's Title: With First Dibs on Vaccines, Rich Countries Have ‘Cleared the Shelves’
Post's Text: The U.S., Britain, Canada and other wealthy countries are reserving coronavirus vaccine doses that far outnumber their populations, as many poorer nations struggle to secure enough.

Post's Title: Trapped at Home in the Pandemic With Mold and a Leaky Roof
Post's Text: "It's a shame we have to live like this."  While the wealthy upgrade their homes, the pandemic has trapped many poor New Yorkers in miserable living conditions in the city’s public housing system.

Post's Title: A new survey finds that about a quarter of Americans don’t want to get vaccinated.
Post's Text: More than a quarter of Americans say they probably or definitely would not take a coronavirus vaccine, new data shows.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: Tens of thousands of people have already received the coronavirus vaccines, and none of them have reported any serious health problems.   For more answers to commonly asked questions about the Covid-19 vaccine rollout in the U.S, see here: https://nyti.ms/34tXESj

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: More than 300,000 people have died because of the coronavirus in the U.S. It is more than the number of Americans who died fighting in World War II. It is roughly half the number of total cancer deaths expected this year. https://nyti.ms/3gOZSRa

Post's Title: Before vaccinations, a logistical feat.
Post's Text: Before medical workers can begin administering Covid-19 vaccinations, they must unpack the doses and move them into an ultracold freezer — a delicate, timed dance that needs to happen in under five minutes to ensure the vaccine’s effectiveness.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: Angela Mattingly, a hospital housekeeper in Iowa, was one of the first people in the U.S. to receive the coronavirus vaccine on Monday. Mattingly has been cleaning the rooms of people with Covid-19 since the start of the pandemic. https://nyti.ms/2KtwJyQ

Post's Title: How Many Vaccine Doses Will Your State Get?
Post's Text: There’s no publicly available national data on how many coronavirus vaccine doses will be sent to each state. The New York Times surveyed all 50 state health departments and territorial governments for their estimates.

Post's Title: See Coronavirus Restrictions and Mask Mandates for All 50 States
Post's Text: The latest on coronavirus restrictions in the United States:  — Indoor dining is closed in New York City as of today — Restaurants and bars in Kentucky can reopen for indoor dining — Massachusetts has closed indoor theaters   Look up the restrictions in your state.

Post's Title: Vaccine Arrives in New York, Hard Hit in Outbreak’s Early Days
Post's Text: New York’s first coronavirus vaccines have arrived, signaling a turning point in the battle against a pandemic that has profoundly scarred the state.

Post's Title: Germany Locks Down Ahead of Christmas as Coronavirus Deaths Rise
Post's Text: Germans will be forced into a strict lockdown over Christmas, after weeks of milder restrictions on public life failed to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

Post's Title: 2020 Was Especially Deadly. Covid Wasn’t the Only Culprit.
Post's Text: The U.S. has recorded 356,000 more deaths than usual this year. A New York Times analysis found that more than a quarter of those deaths weren't caused by Covid-19, though many of them are most likely misattributed, or indirectly related to the virus.

Post's Title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Sends Up Fauci and Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout
Post's Text: Kate McKinnon added Dr. Anthony Fauci to her repertoire this weekend on SNL, imploring the audience not to cheer because, "As you all know, woos spread droplets.”

Post's Title: Federal authorities charge two men with stealing 192 ventilators bound for El Salvador.
Post's Text: Two men have been charged with stealing 192 ventilators owned by the U.S. government in Miami, authorities said on Friday.  When they were stolen, the ventilators — worth $3 million — were being transported to a Covid-19 intensive care center in El Salvador to treat critically ill patients as part of a federal aid program.

Post's Title: C.D.C. panel endorses Pfizer vaccine for people over 16.
Post's Text: New: An independent committee of advisers to the CDC has endorsed Pfizer's coronavirus vaccine for people over the age of 16.

Post's Title: Cuomo Tries to Jolt Public by Warning of Overwhelmed Hospitals
Post's Text: Amid a surge of coronavirus cases in New York, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has shifted from focusing on local clusters of infections to issuing warnings about overwhelmed hospitals.

Post's Title: First Coronavirus Vaccines to Head to States, Starting Historic Effort
Post's Text: This weekend, 2.9 million doses of Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine will travel by plane and guarded truck to all 50 states, kicking off the most ambitious vaccination campaign in American history.

Post's Title: Biden is considering Cuomo for attorney general.
Post's Text: President-elect Joe Biden is eyeing Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, whom Democrats praised for his handling of the coronavirus, for attorney general.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: The U.S. became the sixth country to approve Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine. An initial shipment of about 2.9 million doses of the vaccine will be sent around the country over the next week.   Read more: https://nyti.ms/37TaJp3

Post's Title: To build confidence, Fauci says he’ll ‘get vaccinated publicly.’
Post's Text: Dr. Anthony Fauci intends to “get vaccinated publicly," to build public confidence in the federal government’s coronavirus vaccine program, he told The New York Times on Friday.

Post's Title: Midtown Is Reeling. Should Its Offices Become Apartments?
Post's Text: New York City's real estate industry is so concerned that shifts in workplace culture caused by the pandemic will be long-lasting that it is promoting a striking proposal: turn more than one million square feet of Manhattan office space into housing.

Post's Title: A State Scientist Questioned Florida’s Virus Data. Now Her Home’s Been Raided.
Post's Text: Florida police agents on Monday raided the home of Rebekah Jones, who was fired from running the state’s coronavirus dashboard. It was the latest chapter in a saga that has always returned to the same question: Can Floridians trust their virus data?

Post's Title: The Receding Horizon of Travel’s Return
Post's Text: The coronavirus has wiped out nearly 3.5 million travel jobs in the U.S. Now, even as vaccines raise hopes for recovery, it might be too late for those who rely on tourism for their livelihoods.

Post's Title: Airlines Gear Up to Transport Vaccines That Could Revive Travel
Post's Text: The airline industry will play a vital role in moving billions of coronavirus vaccine doses in the months ahead, putting underused planes and crews to work while circulating the very medicine that they hope will get people to book tickets again.

Post's Title: ‘Numb’ and ‘Heartbroken,’ the U.S. Confronts Record Virus Deaths
Post's Text: The U.S. set a new daily death record on Wednesday: 3,055 people died from the coronavirus, more than were killed in the Sept. 11 terror attacks or the attack on Pearl Harbor.  But with cases still rising, experts warn “the worst is yet to come.”

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine received a vote of confidence from FDA advisers, clearing the way for the agency to authorize its use. The agency is likely to grant an emergency use authorization within days. https://nyti.ms/3gzyQwR

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: Experts say that baseless claims about how the coronavirus vaccine could cause infertility in women are “particularly damaging” to the scientifically backed efforts to protect people with vaccines. https://nyti.ms/2Ltv4d7

Post's Title: An expert panel will decide Thursday whether to recommend that the F.D.A. authorize Pfizer’s vaccine.
Post's Text: The FDA’s vaccine advisory panel is meeting on Thursday to discuss whether the agency should authorize Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine. If the group votes in favor of the vaccine, it will clear the way for the FDA to authorize it within days.

Post's Title: Unemployment claims rose sharply last week as economic crisis grinds on.
Post's Text: Breaking News: State unemployment claims jumped sharply last week, as the economic crisis caused by the pandemic grinds on.

Post's Title: Why Did the U.S. Turn Down Vaccine Doses?
Post's Text: The Trump administration turned down an offer from Pfizer months ago to secure 100 million more doses of its coronavirus vaccine. Why? Listen to today’s episode of The Daily.

Post's Title: An Unwelcome Silent Night: Germany Without Christmas Markets
Post's Text: "The coronavirus is muting Christmas celebrations around the world. But the absence of seasonal merriment and public cheer is particularly palpable, and painful, in Germany’s marketplaces and squares," writes Melissa Eddy.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: New studies suggest that Black and Hispanic Americans are more likely to get sick and die from Covid-19 not because of innate vulnerability. Instead, they are more often exposed to the virus because of social and environmental factors, experts said. https://nyti.ms/2Ke8STG

Post's Title: Holidays in a Pandemic? Here’s What Happened in 1918
Post's Text: Hundreds of thousands of people lost loved ones during the 1918 pandemic. Archived letters and news reports show that when families gathered for the winter holidays, many of them had an empty chair at the table.

Post's Title: Intensive Care Beds Are Nearing Capacity Across the Country, New Data Shows
Post's Text: Over a third of Americans live in areas where hospitals, hit hard by Covid-19, reported critical shortages of intensive-care beds, The New York Times found.

Post's Title: Britain Begins Coronavirus Vaccine Rollout
Post's Text: Stored in deep freezers, defrosted and filled into individual syringes, the coronavirus vaccine was given to variously jubilant and needle-shy Britons on Tuesday. https://nyti.ms/3lRXmKI

Post's Title: Frustration at Britain’s Ports Over Travel Restrictions
Post's Text: The logjam of thousands of Europe-bound trucks stuck in southeast England will take days to clear because drivers must show a negative coronavirus test before they can cross the channel. https://nyti.ms/2LVjqrq

Post's Title: Switzerland begins Covid-19 vaccinations.
Post's Text: A 90-year-old woman living in a retirement home in Lucerne, Switzerland, was the first person in the country to receive the Covid-19 vaccine on Wednesday.

Post's Title: Jose Garcia, New Mexico Farmworker, Dies at 68
Post's Text: Jose Garcia, a New Mexico farmworker, has died of complications related to Covid-19. He was 68.   One of his nine children, a nurse at the hospital, was the only family member allowed to visit him as he battled Covid-19.

Post's Title: Buried in Pandemic Aid Bill: Billions to Soothe the Richest
Post's Text: Tucked away in the 5,593-page coronavirus relief and spending bill that Congress rushed through on Monday night is a provision that some tax experts call a $200 billion giveaway to the rich.

Post's Title: Our Digital Lives Drive a Brick-and-Mortar Boom in Data Centers
Post's Text: Data centers have become a bright spot in commercial real estate, an industry hammered by the pandemic. “You think about data as an intangible asset, but data has to be stored somewhere,” an industry expert says.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: The winter solstice arrives in the depths of the pandemic. But the season of darkness also offers ancient lessons of survival, hope and renewal. https://nyti.ms/2KSmMv2

Post's Title: Biden is expected to name Connecticut’s schools chief as his education secretary.
Post's Text: Joe Biden is expected to nominate Miguel Cardona, Connecticut’s education commissioner, to serve as education secretary.  He would be tasked with repairing the considerable damage done to elementary, secondary and higher education systems by the pandemic.

Post's Title: Family of U.S. Student Jailed for Quarantine Violation Pleads for Her Release
Post's Text: The grandmother of an 18-year-old college student who broke the Cayman Islands’ coronavirus laws on a trip last month is pleading for her release from prison. “She knows she made a mistake. She owns up to that, but she’s pretty hysterical right now.”

Post's Title: For Europe, It’s Wave After Wave
Post's Text: When the coronavirus first struck Europe, it nearly broke its hospitals — exhausting, infecting and killing doctors and nurses. Now, the continent has watched with horror as another virus wave strikes with nearly equal force — and in some places far more.

Post's Title: Congress Rushes to Pass Huge Coronavirus Relief Bill
Post's Text: Breaking News: The House approved a $900 billion pandemic aid bill that will now go to the Senate, where its passage is expected soon. The long-sought relief package provides a $600 payment for most Americans.

Post's Title: Biden receives the coronavirus vaccine.
Post's Text: Breaking News: President-elect Joe Biden received the coronavirus vaccine on live television, sending a message to Americans that it’s safe to take.

Post's Title: Climate Change Legislation Included in Coronavirus Relief Deal
Post's Text: Congressional negotiators inserted a bipartisan measure to curtail planet-warming chemicals used in ACs and fridges in the coronavirus relief package. The legislation would be the first significant climate change law to pass Congress since at least 2009.

Post's Title: Hang in there, help is on the way
Post's Text: If we can safely soldier through these next few months of the pandemic, then normal life — or at least a new version of normal — will be within reach. Here's how to do it:

Post's Title: Feeling Socially Awkward? Even Extroverts Are a Little Rusty
Post's Text: Today’s Great Read: Months of limited mingling during the pandemic have made even extremely outgoing people uncomfortable socializing, “like awkward eighth graders attending a school dance for the first time.”

Post's Title: E.U. regulators approve the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, clearing the way for a rollout.
Post's Text: Breaking News: The European Union drugs agency granted authorization to the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine, clearing the way for a rollout by year’s end.

Post's Title: The New R.S.V.P.: A Signed Coronavirus ‘Waiver’
Post's Text: Coronavirus waivers that must be returned with your RSVP are becoming a new norm for social events this season, including holiday parties, birthdays, weddings, proms, large-scale celebrations and even family reunions.

Post's Title: Thailand announces its biggest outbreak to date, linked to a shrimp market.
Post's Text: After seemingly halting local transmission of the coronavirus with tightened borders and rigorous contact tracing, health authorities in Thailand announced the country’s biggest outbreak to date: 689 infections, all linked to a single shrimp market.

Post's Title: The C.D.C. advisory panel has endorsed the Moderna vaccine.
Post's Text: The CDC advisory panel has endorsed the Moderna vaccine, signaling to hospitals and doctors that they may proceed in giving it to patients. The first vaccinations are expected to begin on Monday.

Post's Title: The U.S. has recorded over 250,000 cases in a day for the first time.
Post's Text: The U.S. recorded over 250,000 coronavirus cases in a day for the first time on Friday, a grim new milestone in the wake of vaccine approvals.

Post's Title: Employers Can Require Workers to Get Covid-19 Vaccine, U.S. Says
Post's Text: The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said employees could be barred from the workplace if they refused the vaccine.

Post's Title: F.D.A. OKs the Moderna Covid Vaccine, Adding Millions More Doses to the U.S. Supply
Post's Text: Breaking News: The FDA authorized Moderna’s vaccine for emergency use. It’s easier to store and handle than Pfizer’s, speeding access to more parts of the U.S.

Post's Title: As Singapore Ventures Back Out, Migrant Workers Are Kept In
Post's Text: Almost half of all migrant workers in Singapore have contracted the coronavirus. The low-wage workers continue to be mostly confined to crowded dormitories.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: Nearly a year after the start of the coronavirus outbreak, the full impact of the pandemic on the U.S. economy remains unclear. Although unemployment has fallen from the worst months, gaps among different demographic groups have widened.  Here's how experts measure the state of the economy:  https://nyti.ms/3h037Fu

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: The U.S. is one step closer to getting back to normal as the first Covid vaccinations of health care workers roll out. We asked Dr. Anthony Fauci, epidemiologists, and New York Times health and science writers for their predictions about the month ahead. https://nyti.ms/2LD8Kxs

Post's Title: First Vaccines Arrive At U.S.'s Long-Term Care Facilities
Post's Text: The first vaccines have now been administered at long-term care facilities in several U.S. states. At one facility in West Virginia, where five residents have died, the news arrived with fist bumps and applause. https://nyti.ms/3alOJpB

Post's Title: No, There Are No Microchips in Coronavirus Vaccines
Post's Text: There are 10 ingredients in Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine. Contrary to conspiracy theories, tracking microchips are not one of them.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: Moderna's coronavirus vaccine is one step closer to FDA emergency use authorization, which is expected to come Friday. https://nyti.ms/2Kexz2y

Post's Title: Emmanuel Macron Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
Post's Text: President Emmanuel Macron of France testing positive for the coronavirus has prompted other European leaders he has met with recently to take their own isolation measures, complicating Europe’s efforts to overcome a crippling second wave of the pandemic.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: The coronavirus vaccines are giving people hope at a time of record-setting numbers of coronavirus cases that are overwhelming hospitals. One New York Times reader shared their memories of another historic vaccine. https://nyti.ms/37swuNm

Post's Title: New York Spent $1 Billion on Virus Supplies. Now It Wants Money Back.
Post's Text: New York City and state officials are trying to recover millions of dollars from quick deals made during the worst weeks of the coronavirus pandemic this spring.

Post's Title: This Is Not the Way New Yorkers Normally Greet a Major Snowstorm
Post's Text: A major nor’easter would normally be a nightmare for New York City. “But this is 2020,” our reporter Michael Wilson writes. “And in the sort of reversal that could only happen in this pandemic era, a heavy snowstorm is, to many, a most welcome change.”

Post's Title: Waste, Negligence and Cronyism: Inside Britain’s Pandemic Spending
Post's Text: In its efforts to procure supplies to fight the coronavirus, Britain has awarded thousands of contracts worth billions of dollars. Much of that money has gone to companies either run by friends and associates of Conservative Party politicians, or with no experience or a history of controversy, a New York Times analysis found.

Post's Title: Dawn Wells, Mary Ann on ‘Gilligan’s Island,’ Dies at 82
Post's Text: She radiated all-American wholesomeness, Midwestern practicality and a youthful naïve charm as Mary Ann on the hit 1960s sitcom “Gilligan’s Island.” The actress Dawn Wells has died from Covid-19 related issues at 82.

Post's Title: The State of the Virus: 2020 in Review
Post's Text: More than 19 million people in the U.S. are known to have had the coronavirus. More than 338,000 of them have died. And in the final weeks of 2020, we’ve continued to set new records in cases and deaths. Here’s a look back at how the virus spread.

Post's Title: Hit Hard by the Pandemic, Mexico’s Drug Cartels Tweaked Their Playbook
Post's Text: Faced with lockdowns and border closures, Mexico's drug cartels got creative, increasing their use of tools like drones and tunnels. The changes have allowed them to rebound quickly even as the pandemic continues to devastate economies.

Post's Title: Britain Authorizes Covid Vaccine From Oxford and AstraZeneca
Post's Text: Breaking News: Britain became the first country to authorize the cheap and easy-to-store coronavirus vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford.

Post's Title: How the Pandemic Has Been Devastating for Children From Low-Income Families
Post's Text: In communities struggling with poverty and gun violence, the coronavirus has only inflamed the difficulties that many families already were enduring.

Post's Title: The grandmother who was the first to get the vaccine in Britain gets her second dose.
Post's Text: The first patient in Britain to receive the coronavirus vaccine received her second jab on Tuesday, making her the first publicly known person to be fully vaccinated against the virus outside a clinical trial.

Post's Title: New Data Triples Russia’s Covid-19 Death Toll
Post's Text: Russia's death toll from Covid-19 is more than three times as high as officially reported, according to new data from the nation's statistical agency.

Post's Title: With No Tickets to Sell, Arts Groups Appeal to Donors to Survive
Post's Text: Virtual cocktail parties, music quizzes, meet-the-musician online events. As cultural institutions struggle to pay their operating costs, the pandemic has forced many of these nonprofits to find creative ways to interact with donors.

Post's Title: More people were screened at U.S. airports on Sunday than on any other day since mid-March.
Post's Text: Sunday was the busiest day for U.S. airports since mid-March, underscoring concerns that a spike in holiday travel may contribute to the spread of the coronavirus.

Post's Title: What the Vaccine Side Effects Feel Like, According to Those Who’ve Gotten It
Post's Text: "It felt like I got smacked,” one Rhode Island doctor said of the headache she had after receiving a Covid-19 vaccine. Like everyone we talked to about vaccine side-effects, she also said she would take it again in a heartbeat.

Post's Title: Spain plans to set up a registry that will list those who refuse to get a Covid-19 vaccine.
Post's Text: Spain plans to collect and share with other European Union nations information about residents who refuse to get vaccinated for Covid-19, the country’s health minister said.

Post's Title: Early Vaccine Doubters Now Show a Willingness to Roll Up Their Sleeves
Post's Text: The number of people saying they are now likely or certain to get the coronavirus vaccine in the U.S. has grown, according to new surveys. Polls show that skepticism is melting, partly because of the images of people getting the shot.

Post's Title: Duke Women’s Basketball Ends Season Early Because of Virus Concerns
Post's Text: Duke University’s women’s basketball program ended its season early because of coronavirus concerns. The men’s team is expected to continue playing.

Post's Title: Boston Doctor Reports Serious Allergic Reaction After Getting Moderna’s Covid Vaccine
Post's Text: A Boston physician said he developed a severe allergic reaction after receiving Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine on Thursday. He self-administered his EpiPen and recovered quickly. Severe allergic reactions from the vaccine remain a rarity, experts said.

Post's Title: Disadvantaged Students More Likely to Be Learning Remotely, Study Finds
Post's Text: Disadvantaged students are much more likely than others to be engaged in remote schooling during the pandemic, increasing the risk that less effective instruction will widen the achievement gap, according to an analysis of attendance patterns.

Post's Title: Covid-19 Patient Is Bludgeoned to Death in California Hospital
Post's Text: An 82-year-old man who was being treated for Covid-19 at a hospital north of Los Angeles was bludgeoned to death with an oxygen tank last week by his roommate, the authorities said.

Post's Title: Virginia Shackles, Painter of Vivid Scenery, Dies at 99
Post's Text: Virginia Shackles, a vivid landscape painter who used watercolor and oil paints to depict scenery from beloved places, died of complications from Covid-19. She was 99.

Post's Title: Chief Justice Praises the Courts’ Responses to the Pandemic
Post's Text: Courts in the U.S. have reacted nimbly to the coronavirus pandemic, Chief Justice John Roberts wrote in his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary.  "For the past 10 months, it has been all hands on deck for the courts," he wrote.

Post's Title: F.D.A. Clears Johnson & Johnson’s Shot, the Third Vaccine for U.S.
Post's Text: Breaking News: The FDA authorized Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine, the first that requires only a single shot. Distribution is expected to begin soon.

Post's Title: ‘Captain Tom,’ British Pandemic Hero, Is Honored at Funeral
Post's Text: Watch: "Captain Tom," a 100-year-old World War II veteran who raised millions for Britain’s National Health Service during the pandemic by walking laps in his garden, received military honors at his funeral on Saturday. https://nyti.ms/3ksrehL

Post's Title: Vulnerable Inmates Left in Prison as Covid Rages
Post's Text: Pregnant, she slept near a coughing inmate as the virus spread. Federal prisons have faltered on orders to move vulnerable prisoners to home confinement to protect them from the coronavirus.

Post's Title: Assessing Claims in the Coronavirus Stimulus Debate
Post's Text: Lawmakers have made an array of misleading claims as they debate the $1.9 trillion relief bill, including that only 9% will go to Covid-19 relief. Here’s a fact check of some common talking points: https://nyti.ms/3q1EVFi

Post's Title: Amid Slow Vaccine Deliveries, Desperate E.U. Nations Hunt for More
Post's Text: Amid anger over a slow vaccine rollout, some E.U. countries are trying to negotiate directly with drug makers. Many nations are also eyeing offers from each other, from Russia and China, and from private brokers, some of whom are fraudsters.

Post's Title: Israel reopens to fully vaccinated ‘Green Pass’ holders — nearly half of the population.
Post's Text: In Israel, Green Pass holders, meaning people over 16 who are fully vaccinated, are now able to enjoy a variety of pre-pandemic activities.

Post's Title: Why Virus Variants Have Such Weird Names
Post's Text: Assigning clear names to the coronavirus variants has become a source of stress for scientists. A few of the suggestions for name inspiration: hurricanes, Greek letters, birds, other animal names like red squirrel or aardvark, and local monsters.

Post's Title: DeSantis Is Ascendant and Cuomo Is Faltering
Post's Text: Governor Andrew Cuomo and Governor Ron DeSantis have both been on the front lines of the government’s pandemic response. But recent twists in their political fortunes underscore how differently both parties are keeping score in this volatile moment.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: A nurse in Baton Rouge is on a one-woman mission to get older African-Americans to take the coronavirus vaccine after her husband died from the virus. https://nyti.ms/3bmNeYv

Post's Title: Annmarie Reinhart Smith, Who Battled for Retail Workers, Dies at 61
Post's Text: After nearly three decades with Toys “R” Us, Annmarie Reinhart Smith helped lead a fight by employees for severance pay from the bankrupt company. She died at 61 due to complications of Covid-19.

Post's Title: As states loosen restrictions and variants spread, Fauci warns that the U.S. could be headed for yet another virus spike.
Post's Text: States have continued steadily lifting restrictions, despite warnings from top federal health officials like Dr. Anthony Fauci that new coronavirus cases in the United States have plateaued at a very high level.

Post's Title: How Rhode Island Fell to the Coronavirus
Post's Text: Rhode Island was lauded for curbing the coronavirus, then it became one of the most infected places in the U.S. What went wrong?

Post's Title: A High B.M.I. Can Get You Vaccinated Earlier, Junk Science or Not
Post's Text: Millions of Americans in states like New York, Utah and Texas are qualified to be vaccinated for the coronavirus based on their BMI. But for many, using the flawed metric to get inoculated is a fraught decision.

Post's Title: To Stay or Go? Even With Vaccines, Travel Planning Remains Complicated
Post's Text: Vaccines are just one piece of the puzzle. Shifting hot spots, regularly changing state and country restrictions and testing requirements remain a concern for many would-be travelers.

Post's Title: Protesters and Police Clash in Paraguay Amid Anger Over Pandemic Response
Post's Text: Protesters clashed with police in Paraguay’s capital, Asunción, late on Friday as anger over the government’s handling of the coronavirus crisis boiled onto the streets and forced the resignation of the country’s top health official.

Post's Title: A new poll finds 70 percent of Americans approve of Biden’s virus response.
Post's Text: President Biden is enjoying a level of popularity his poll-obsessed predecessor never came close to achieving — a 60% approval rating — with 70% of Americans expressing support for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic, according to a new poll.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos
Post's Text: With coronavirus cases in the U.S. as low as they’ve been in months and vaccination ramping up, states have rolled back restrictions in recent days. But the virus is far from under control.  Here's what to know about the pandemic this week. https://nyti.ms/3blUjZb

Post's Title: For the Economy, the Present Doesn’t Matter. It’s All About the Near Future.
Post's Text: “In normal times, the total employment gains reported Friday would be a blockbuster number,” our senior economics correspondent Neil Irwin writes. “But continuing to add jobs at that pace would still mean a two-year grind back to pre-pandemic employment levels.”

Post's Title: Canada approves the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, giving it a fourth option.
Post's Text: Breaking News: Canada authorized use of Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine, giving the country access to a fourth shot as it seeks to speed up a lagging vaccination campaign.

Post's Text: Pope Francis starts his three-day visit to Iraq on Friday, his first trip since the pandemic began and the first time a head of the Catholic Church is believed to have visited the country.   Follow our updates.

Post's Title: China subjects some travelers to anal swabs, angering foreign governments.

Post's Text: Public health officials are enthusiastic about Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine because of how much faster they could get a single shot distributed, particularly in vulnerable communities that might not otherwise have access to a vaccine.

Post's Text: An Indian drug company said that initial results from clinical trials showed that a homegrown Indian vaccine was safe and effective. The Covaxin vaccine had an initial efficacy rate of 81%, Bharat Biotech said.

Post's Text: Pulling off successful men’s and women’s college basketball tournaments during a pandemic is “going to be complicated and difficult,” an NCAA basketball official said. Financially, it may be essential.

Post's Text: Israel has outpaced much of the world with its coronavirus vaccine rollout. For some in the country, life is slowly returning to normal.  How is Israel managing life after vaccination? Listen to today’s episode of The Daily.

Post's Title: How the Pandemic Changed the Way We Read
Post's Text: Many of us turned to books for comfort, distraction and escape in a tremendously upsetting year.  The result? Print book sales had their best year in a decade, according to NPD BookScan. Here’s what else we found:

Post's Title: One Year in a Pandemic: Your Weekend Briefing
Post's Text: This week was the anniversary of the World Health Organization’s declaring a global pandemic, but also of something deeper: It has been a year since we had to unexpectedly and dramatically alter the way we live. https://nyti.ms/3tvIKFd

Post's Title: Yo-Yo Ma gives a surprise cello concert at a Massachusetts vaccination site.

Post's Title: Dench, Smith, McKellen, Jacobi: On a Vanishing Era of Theater Greats
Post's Text: Because of the pandemic (and their advancing age), we might have seen some of the finest actors of a generation, including Judi Dench, Maggie Smith and Ian McKellen, for the last time on stage.

Post's Title: Should I Come Out to My Parents?
Post's Text: "I am a queer high school senior and the daughter of evangelical Christians. I have kept my sexuality secret from them. During the pandemic, I got lonely, so I started chatting on LGBTQ message boards. Unfortunately, I was careless with my browser history. My mother saw it and freaked out. She made me swear I’m not a lesbian. I did. My parents are also making me talk to their minister every week. If I don’t, they say I will have to leave home. They also threatened not to help with college costs next year. (They’re not kidding.) So, now I’m lying to their minister too. I hate this! I like to think of myself as a good person. Should I come clean?"

Post's Title: There Is No Vaccine for Grief
Post's Text: “We live in a society that minimizes grief...We try to stay a mile ahead of it, but it’s just always there, chasing behind us.”

Post's Title: Covid? What Covid? Taiwan Thrives as a Bubble of Normality
Post's Text: Taiwan, which has seen just 10 Covid-19 deaths and fewer than 1,000 cases, has used its success to sell something in short supply: living without fear of the coronavirus.

Post's Title: ‘I’d Much Rather Be in Florida’
Post's Text: For better or worse, Florida’s experiment in returning to life-as-it-used-to-be offers a glimpse of what many states are likely to face in the weeks ahead, as they move into the next phase of the pandemic — the part where it starts to be over.

Post's Title: Despite Covid Limits, Mourners Rally for Slain London Woman

Post's Title: Which Families Will Receive the Most Money From the Stimulus Bill?
Post's Text: The stimulus bill President Biden signed on Thursday includes a larger increase in direct payments to families than any other pandemic relief bill passed yet. By some estimates, the bill could cut child poverty in half this year.  Here's who will benefit.

Post's Title: Despite Encouraging Downward Trend, U.S. Covid Deaths Remain High
Post's Text: Coronavirus cases are trending downward across the U.S., but the death rate remains at nearly 1,500 people every day, exceeding the peak observed in the summer.

Post's Title: A vigil for a woman killed in Britain is canceled over Covid restrictions.
Post's Text: The organizers of a vigil for Sarah Everard, a 33-year-old woman who went missing in London last week and whose body was identified on Friday, canceled the gathering after authorities warned they'd face a hefty fine for violating Covid restrictions.

Post's Title: Opinion | They Escaped New York During the Pandemic. Make Them Pay.
Post's Text: In The New York Times Opinion Section  "I believe I speak for all pandemic-weathered New York City residents when I say that we cannot let these transplants off so easy. This indiscretion shall not stand," writes Luke Winkie, a writer who stayed in Brooklyn through the pandemic.

Post's Title: As more of the U.S. returns to indoor dining, restaurant workers clamor for vaccine access.
Post's Text: Only about a third of U.S. states have made restaurant workers eligible for the coronavirus vaccine.

Post's Title: Novavax reports strong trial results in Britain and weaker ones in South Africa.
Post's Text: The drug company Novavax said that its coronavirus vaccine candidate had an efficacy rate of 96.4% in a Phase 3 trial in Britain, but was only 48.6% effective in a Phase 2 trial in South Africa, where most cases are linked to an emerging variant.

Post's Title: U.S. Health Officials Question AstraZeneca Vaccine Trial Results

Post's Title: AstraZeneca’s Latest Stumble Again Clouds European Vaccinations
Post's Text: AstraZeneca’s latest blunder has further undercut the effort to sell people on one of the most potent and indispensable coronavirus vaccines, scientists say.

Post's Title: They Had Mild Covid. Then Their Serious Symptoms Kicked In.
Post's Text: A new study illuminates long-term neurological symptoms in people who had mild cases of Covid, underscoring an emerging understanding that for many people, long Covid can be worse than their initial bouts with the infection.

Post's Title: U.S. Health Officials Question AstraZeneca Vaccine Trial Results
Post's Text: U.S. officials said AstraZeneca might have included outdated information from its Covid-19 vaccine trial, providing an “incomplete” view of the data. https://nyti.ms/394P1zS

Post's Title: As Europe’s Lockdowns Drag on, Police and Protesters Clash More
Post's Text: Protesters on both the left and right across Europe have poured into the streets to lash out against coronavirus restrictions. The often harsh responses from the police are raising questions about the legitimacy of law enforcement.

Post's Title: U.S. health officials question results from AstraZeneca’s vaccine trial hours after they’re released.
Post's Text: Breaking News: U.S. officials said AstraZeneca might have included outdated information from its Covid-19 vaccine trial, providing an “incomplete” view of the data.

Post's Title: Some Nations Could Wait Years for Covid Shots. That’s Bad for Everyone.
Post's Text: Roughly three-quarters of the Covid vaccines given globally have gone to only 10 countries. At least 30 countries have not yet injected a single person. Scientists warn that such unfair treatment could not only haunt poorer countries, but also rich ones.

Post's Title: Covid Has Traumatized America. A Doctor Explains What We Need to Heal.
Post's Text: "It is repressed and treated with denial. That doesn’t make it go away. It’s controlling how people respond to new trauma, whether it’s a diagnosis or a pandemic or a January 6th." A palliative-care doctor talks to the New York Times Magazine about trauma and healing in the U.S.

Post's Title: Fauci Addresses the Safety of the AstraZeneca Vaccine
Post's Text: A U.S. trial found AstraZeneca’s Covid-19 vaccine was 79% effective with no serious side effects. Dr. Anthony Fauci on Monday discussed the results of the trial. https://nyti.ms/2P1jbNk

Post's Title: How Much Weight Did We Gain During Lockdowns? 2 Pounds a Month, Study Hints
Post's Text: Many Americans know they’ve put on weight during the pandemic, but it’s been difficult for experts to detail the scope. One small study suggests that adults under shelter-in-place orders across the U.S. gained nearly two pounds a month.

Post's Title: If Everything Smells Bad, You’re Not Alone
Post's Text: The phantom odors and distorted sense of smell that can linger after Covid-19 have made an already-isolating year worse for people affected by the condition, parosmia.   Pleasant aromas, like a delicious meal or the scent of a romantic partner, turn foul.

Post's Title: Opinion | The AstraZeneca Vaccine Is Safe. How Can We Get People to Trust It?
Post's Text: In The New York Times Opinion Section   “In our scientific rush to develop, manufacture and deliver vaccines more rapidly than ever in history, countries around the world have failed to engage the public,” writes Heidi Larson, an anthropologist and expert on vaccine confidence.

Post's Title: Kent Taylor, Texas Roadhouse Founder and C.E.O., Dies at 65
Post's Text: Kent Taylor, the founder and chief executive of the Texas Roadhouse restaurant chain, died by suicide on Thursday after suffering “post-Covid-related symptoms, including severe tinnitus,” the company and his family said in a statement. He was 65.

Post's Title: Timeline Photos

Post's Title: AstraZeneca’s Covid-19 Vaccine Found to Be 79% Effective in U.S. Study
Post's Text: Breaking News: A U.S. trial found AstraZeneca’s Covid-19 vaccine was 79% effective with no serious side effects. The company will seek emergency FDA authorization.

Post's Title: How Two Lonely Generations Are Helping Each Other Heal
Post's Text: There’s been a blossoming of creativity in bringing young and old together since the onset of the pandemic — and their partnerships have helped both generations get through it.

Post's Title: What Will Your ‘After’ Look Like?
Post's Text: We want to hear what readers predict, fear and hope for a gradual shift to a post-pandemic world. Tell us what you imagine your After will look like using the form inside this article.

Post's Title: What Loss Looks Like: Share an Object of Remembrance
Post's Text: At a time when we cannot honor our loved ones together, we are creating a virtual memorial. Show us the artifacts that help you memorialize those you lost during the pandemic and they may be included in our upcoming project.

Post's Title: Fully Vaccinated and Time to Party: If You Are 70
Post's Text: Older people, who represent the vast majority of Americans who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, are filling restaurants, hugging grandchildren and booking flights after enduring a long, painful period of isolation.

Post's Title: After Tony Hsieh’s Shocking Death, Zappos Looks to Move Forward
Post's Text: Following former Zappos CEO Tony Hsieh's untimely death, his successor, Kedar Deshpande, faces the challenge of leading the shoe seller out of the pandemic, while also maintaining what his predecessor built.

Post's Title: In Hawaii, Reimagining Tourism for a Post-Pandemic World
Post's Text: Before the pandemic, tourism in Hawaii had become “extractive and hurtful,” said a farmer and chef in Oahu. Now the state, like other overtouristed places, is hoping for a reset.

Post's Title: New York reports its first case of the troubling variant that is dominant in Brazil.
Post's Text: New York has reported its first confirmed case of the worrisome coronavirus variant first found in Brazil.  The variant, known as P.1, is highly contagious and has in some cases reinfected people who have already recovered from the virus.

Post's Title: We Asked Teens What Life Was Like in a Pandemic. They Had a Lot to Say.
Post's Text: Last fall, when The New York Times Learning Network invited teenagers across the United States to tell us what living in a pandemic was like, we didn’t expect so many answers — nor did we expect those answers to take quite so many different forms.

Post's Text: Two episodes of “SpongeBob SquarePants” have been removed from Nickelodeon — one because of sensitivity related to the pandemic and another for not being “kid-appropriate” — the network said on Tuesday.

Post's Text: Offices are being reimagined as companies adjust to new ways of working brought about by the pandemic.  Bigger meeting spaces, increased videoconferencing facilities and more hot desks could all be coming to an office near you.

Post's Title: Virus Origins Remain Unclear in W.H.O.-China Inquiry
Post's Text: An international team of experts has left Wuhan, China, still far from understanding the origins of the coronavirus pandemic that has killed nearly 2.8 million people worldwide. And it is not clear whether China will permit outside experts to keep digging.

Post's Title: Behind Closed Doors, ‘the Difficulty and the Beauty’ of Pandemic Hospice Work
Post's Text: “I often want to hug the family members, but I cannot do that now.”  The coronavirus pandemic has deprived families and caretakers of ways to grieve together, and confronted hospice workers, however familiar with death, with a staggering scale of loss.

Post's Title: New York Must Offer Vaccine to All Prisoners Immediately, Judge Rules
Post's Text: Breaking News: New York must immediately begin to offer Covid vaccines to all incarcerated people in the state’s prisons and jails, a judge ruled on Monday, saying that they had been arbitrarily excluded in the vaccine rollout.

Post's Title: Edward Jenner Pioneered Vaccination. Will His Museum Survive a Pandemic?
Post's Text: The "Temple of Vaccinia," where, more than 220 years ago, the residents of an English village lined up for the first vaccine for smallpox, is one of the hundreds of British museums struggling to survive the coronavirus pandemic.

Post's Title: The Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines are very effective in real-world conditions at preventing infections, the C.D.C. reported.

Post's Title: Remote Work Is Here to Stay. Manhattan May Never Be the Same.
Post's Text: The coronavirus prompted a tectonic shift in how and where many people work. Manhattan, an island whose economy has been sustained by more than 1.6 million daily commuters, could be changed forever.  Tell us about your plans to return — or not return — to the office in the comments.

Post's Title: Trump’s former pandemic coordinator suggests restrained response may have cost hundreds of thousands of lives.
Post's Text: Hundreds of thousands of Americans likely died needlessly from Covid-19, Dr. Deborah Birx, a Trump administration official, suggested in a CNN report.

Post's Title: Skiing in Himalayas Is ‘Like a Beautiful Dream,’ Despite Conflict and Coronavirus
Post's Text: While other ski slopes around the world have suffered because of the coronavirus, Gulmarg is having one of its busiest seasons ever. But what is perhaps most striking about its appeal now is that it lies in Kashmir, a territory disputed by India and Pakistan.

Post's Title: I Haven’t Talked to This Asian-American Friend in Years. Should I Call Now?
Post's Text: Since the beginning of the pandemic, I have been shocked by the amount of racist political language aimed at Asian-Americans and the spike in hate crimes against the community. As a white person, I feel ashamed that I didn’t focus on this problem sooner. During this period, I have often thought about a Korean-American woman I worked with several years ago. We grew close and moved our friendship beyond the office (dinners with our partners and theater evenings, etc.). I’d like to check in with her now and express my support over recent events. But it’s been several years since we’ve been in touch, and something is holding me back. What do you think?

Post's Title: His Game Made Beating a Pandemic Fun. Can He Do It for Climate Change?
Post's Text: Matt Leacock, the inventor of the hit board game Pandemic, has spent the past year making a game about an even weightier subject.

Post's Title: New York becomes the first state to have a Covid-19 digital pass.
Post's Text: New York is the first state to formally create a digital passport for those vaccinated against the coronavirus.

Post's Title: Cases in Florida, a national Covid bellwether, are rising — especially among younger people.
Post's Text: Scientists view Florida — the state furthest along in lifting coronavirus restrictions, reopening society and welcoming tourists — as a bellwether for the U.S.  If recent trends there are any indication, the rest of the country may be in trouble.

Post's Title: For Biden, a New Virus Dilemma: How to Handle a Looming Glut of Vaccine
Post's Text: As U.S. vaccine production is projected to exceed demand in late spring, global scarcity threatens to grow more acute. Vaccine makers are looking to President Biden for direction on what to do with the coming surplus.

Post's Title: First Covid, Then Psychosis: ‘The Most Terrifying Thing I’ve Ever Experienced’
Post's Text: A small number of people, like Ivan Agerton, have developed psychotic symptoms as a mysterious aftereffect of Covid-19. After a mild case of Covid, he described being seized by paranoid delusions that turned life into a nightmare.

Post's Title: Opinion | Usually Trump creates his own crises. Coronavirus is the real thing, and he’s bungling it.
Post's Text: "The novel coronavirus is the first major crisis that Trump confronts that he did not create and whose impact he cannot escape with his usual bluster and bravado," Max Boot writes in Opinions.

Post's Title: As coronavirus quietly spread, a nondescript nursing home became the deadliest hot spot in the U.S.
Post's Text: The 69 residents who remain are confined to their rooms.  Staff wearing blue smocks, face masks and gloves tend to them around the clock.

Post's Title: Italian hand sanitizer Amuchina inspires memes as its producer races to meet demand
Post's Text: The coronavirus outbreak has made a $4 product into a precious commodity.

Post's Title: So you’ve been asked to self-quarantine. Here’s what you should know.
Post's Text: When someone is quarantined, that doesn’t mean they are infected with the coronavirus. Here's what you should know.

Post's Title: Opinion | How the populist right is exploiting coronavirus
Post's Text: "Almost everywhere, the populist right is trying to blame the contagion on open borders and migrants," writes Fareed Zakaria in Opinions.

Post's Title: Spiking U.S. coronavirus cases could force rationing decisions similar to those made in Italy, China
Post's Text: Tough choices about which patients get medical care could well be ahead for the United States, a nation with limited hospital capacity and grim epidemiological projections estimating that as many as 40 to 60 percent of the country’s population of 327 million could eventually become infected with the novel coronavirus.

Post's Title: Live updates: D.C. closes nightclubs and restricts bars, restaurants; New cases in Md., Va.; NIH employee tests positive for coronavirus
Post's Text: The District, Maryland and Virginia entered an increasingly anxious shutdown mode because of the novel coronavirus pandemic, with public schools set to close in many districts and large gatherings canceled in Maryland, major tourist sites shuttered throughout the region, and the District and Virginia declaring states of emergency.

Post's Title: Analysis | Steven Mnuchin says Trump didn’t get ‘things wrong at all’ in his coronavirus address. That’s absurd.
Post's Text: Mnuchin said Trump didn't get anything wrong in his address and that his comment on trade being halted as "misinterpreted." That's just not true.

Post's Title: Without guidance from the top, Americans have been left to figure out their own coronavirus solutions
Post's Text: As the country lurched toward its first collective counteroffensive to the rapidly escalating coronavirus crisis, the big and small decisions in the mobilization fell largely to nervous parents, wary pastors, incredulous mayors and harried desk workers who waited in vain for clear guidance from federal authorities.

Post's Title: Live updates: National Institutes of Health staffer has coronavirus; travelers face hours-long delays at U.S. airports
Post's Text: An employee at the National Institutes of Health has tested positive for the coronavirus, according to an email sent to staff. The NIH has been a leader in the U.S. response to the pandemic.

Post's Title: These federal workers were exposed to the coronavirus while serving the public. Now they’re quarantined.

Post's Title: Tracking known coronavirus cases in D.C., Maryland and Virginia

Post's Text: Although some retailers, like Macy’s, have suspended Santa visits or moved them online, many others are forging ahead with extra precautions and backup plans, in hopes of getting customers into stores during a particularly fraught holiday season.

Post's Title: Coronavirus: Vaccine Distribution with Lt. Gen. (Ret.) Paul Ostrowski
Post's Text: As the nation prepares for final vaccine approval, retired Lt. Gen. Paul Ostrowski joins The Post to discuss Operation Warp Speed’s effort to deliver the vaccine safely, securely and as soon as possible to the American people.

Post's Title: Bar owner drove into officer while fleeing arrest for flouting shutdown orders, sheriff says

Post's Title: GLOBAL HANGOUT: Conversations on Coronavirus
Post's Text: GLOBAL HANGOUT: Conversations on Coronavirus -- A managing director of World Economic Forum in Switzerland; a lip gloss-to-hand sanitzer company owner in the US; a street food vendor in Malaysia; and a sales manager in the US.  The expanding global shutdown to fight the coronavirus pandemic is testing governments and pushing economies to the brink. People are being asked to make enormous sacrifices, and there is little indication of how long these measures will be in place, or what the damage will be when they are lifted.   How serious is the economic threat, and is it now being pitted against the health threat?   GUESTS:      Saadia Zahidi Managing Director World Economic Forum Switzerland  Fulziah Muhamad Street food vendor Selangor, Malaysia -Lost job because of lockdown  Dawn Andrews Owner, Garb2ART Columbus, Indiana,USA     -Converted lip gloss company to manufactur hand sanitizer, has hired those laid off      Tyler Blankenship Sales Manager, Garb2ART Columbus, Indiana, USA     -Hired by Garb2ART after being laid off

Post's Title: Frontline medical workers describe their experiences battling coronavirus
Post's Text: Frontline medical workers tell us about their experiences battling coronavirus in Italy, Sri Lanka and the UK:  In countries around the world, #healthcare workers are on the frontline of this global emergency. Everyone is stretched, everyone is at risk. How do the experiences of these professionals compare internationally? Helena Humphrey hosts a conversation between healthcare workers from the epicenter of the crisis, Italy, and the UK, where hospitals are on alert, preparing, anticipating and hoping to avoid what Italy has just experienced. We also get context and analysis from an expert on global healthcare systems, who can tell us just how prepared or unprepared countries are for this #pandemic.   -Dr. Ambra Barco Infectious Diseases Specialist  Ospedale Maggiore della Carità Novara, Italy  -Dr. Sonia Adesara NHS Physician London  -Alanna Shaikh  Global Health Consultant  Colombo, Sri Lanka

Post's Title: ‘Zero chance’ of eliminating Covid-19
Post's Text: With the UK government’s plans for easing lockdown in England unveiled, hopes that the pandemic may be ending have been raised. But a specialist team at Bristol University, who've been working to track the emerging variants of the coronavirus, say the public will have to get used to living with some form of Covid-19 well beyond this year.  (Via BBC Newsnight) bbc.in/37F6uOn

Post's Title: Matt Hancock ‘disrespectful’ over PPE shortage claims
Post's Text: The Health Secretary Matt Hancock came under fire on BBC Question Time for his claims that the country hadn’t suffered a national shortage of PPE during the pandemic. Mr Hancock made the statement in a Today programme interview earlier in the week, saying that while there were “individual challenges in access to PPE”, they “never had a national shortage, because of my team”.  https://bbc.in/3slfwbo

Post's Title: Pandemic hero laid to rest
Post's Text: Captain Sir Tom Moore's funeral has taken place in Bedford attended by eight members of his family.  The 100-year-old war veteran raised millions for the NHS walking laps of his garden in lockdown last year.  https://bbc.in/2O7JqRq

Post's Title: Unequal vaccine deployment ‘risks international development’
Post's Text: Socio-economic improvements in developing countries could be reversed if they do not receive adequate numbers of Covid vaccines at the same time as richer nations, the United Nations Development Programme has warned. Speaking to BBC Newsnight, the UNDP’s Assistant Secretary-General and Regional Director for Africa, Ahunna Eziakonwa, said providing vaccines for low income countries will not only help them, but ensure a quicker end to the pandemic across the world and a faster recovery for the global economy.  https://bbc.in/3bK6M7P

Post's Title: Captain Sir Tom Moore dies with coronavirus
Post's Text: Captain Sir Tom Moore raised almost £33m for the NHS by walking 100 laps of his garden in lockdown, capturing the heart of the nation with every step. Here's a look back at his achievements.  (Via BBC News: East of England) bbc.in/3pTX2h6

Post's Title: Young vulnerable people in UK receive Covid vaccines
Post's Text: Hope, 22, and Adetutu, 30, have both received their first Covid vaccines.  Nearly 200,000 younger people across the UK classed as extremely clinically vulnerable have also had the jab.   https://bbc.in/3r0sEm3

Post's Title: Covid vaccine: What age groups are being vaccinated next?
Post's Text: The next stage of the UK's Covid vaccine rollout has been outlined by government scientists. Here's how it will work.  https://bbc.in/3ktN30j

Post's Title: In Case You Missed It
Post's Text: A Russian art exhibition completely underwater, Covid vaccine celebrations and other stories you may have missed this week.  https://bbc.in/2MUIpw0

Post's Title: Longer school day, shorter summer being considered in England
Post's Text: UK ministers are looking at "how the school year runs" after the disruption of Covid.

Post's Title: What happens when a virus mutates?
Post's Text: Where are Covid variants coming from, and why do viruses mutate?  bbc.in/3bj5Zfm

Post's Title: Film fans want joint release dates for cinema and streaming, Netflix boss says
Post's Text: Cinema bosses said people are "hugely excited" about seeing films on the big screen again, but Netflix thinks the pandemic may have changed things.

Post's Title: Why Magna Carta won’t exempt you from lockdown rules
Post's Text: UK business owners determined to escape Covid restrictions have resorted to citing some rather outdated laws.

Post's Title: Jogging bottoms and hand sanitiser now used to work out cost of living
Post's Text: High demand during the pandemic means a range of new items are now being used by the Office for National Statistics to calculate the cost of living in the UK.

Post's Title: UK vaccination surge expected in coming days
Post's Text: The number of Covid vaccine jabs given in the UK this week is expected to top four million, nearly double what has been achieved per week recently, NHS sources have said.

Post's Title: Ministers criticise PM Boris Johnson over second wave 'denial'
Post's Text: The UK government should have brought in tougher restrictions in the early autumn to tackle the "inevitable" second wave of coronavirus, senior officials have told the BBC.

Post's Title: Netherlands suspends use of AstraZeneca vaccine
Post's Text: It is the latest nation to act over reports of blood clotting, but the World Health Organization said it is safe.

Post's Title: Russia's Putin gets Covid vaccine but without cameras
Post's Text: Vladimir Putin has received the Covid vaccine, partly to encourage other Russians who remain deeply reluctant to get the jab - but chose to be vaccinated behind closed doors.

Post's Title: UK shines a light as it remembers Covid victims
Post's Text: Parts of the UK have been lit up in remembrance of those who have lost their lives in the Covid pandemic as the country marked the first anniversary of its first lockdown.

Post's Title: 'I'll be coming out of this pandemic as a completely different person'
Post's Text: Lockdown isolation helped Nathan, 19, come out as LGBT.

Post's Title: Are Covid vaccine export bans a 'retrograde step'?
Post's Text: "Don't start the export ban, because it's dangerous road."  Anna Cavazzini MEP and Steve Bates, UK BioIndustry Association, discuss whether introducing Covid vaccine export bans would be a "retrograde step".  (via BBC Newsnight)

Post's Title: £5,000 fine for people going on holiday abroad
Post's Text: The penalty is due to come into force in England next week as a surge in Covid cases in Europe has cast doubt on the resumption of foreign travel.

Post's Title: Hundreds descend on Nottingham Arboretum
Post's Text: Crowds of park-goers in Nottingham were seen ignoring social-distancing rules while hugging and brawling, after some Covid restrictions were eased.   The scenes at Nottingham Arboretum came as two households or groups of up to six people were allowed to meet outside in England.  bbc.in/3fpFvuS (via BBC East Midlands)

Post's Title: Half of UK has antibodies from vaccination or infection
Post's Text: Roughly half of people in the UK now have antibodies against Covid, either through infection or vaccination, tests conducted by the Office for National Statistics have shown.

Post's Title: Irish pubs could become work hubs in post-pandemic plan
Post's Text: Sláinte!

Post's Title: Secret filming exposes contamination risk at UK Covid test results lab
Post's Text: An undercover reporter saw practices that could mean people received an incorrect test result.

Post's Title: Sir Lenny Henry urges black Britons to take Covid vaccine in open letter
Post's Text: "Trust science, take the jab."

Post's Title: Past Covid infection increases vaccine response six-fold
Post's Text: Health workers with previous Covid-19 infections had six times the immune response to one dose of the Pfizer jab than those who hadn't had the virus, a study has shown.

Post's Title: Reopening a Theme Park Is a Topsy-Turvy Ride
Post's Text: Theme parks make their money by packing roller coasters with screaming riders and filling wave pools with bobbing bodies. The pandemic upended that model, forcing a 74-year-old amusement palace in southwest Indiana to rethink everything.

Post's Title: TikTok Users Gush About China, Hoping to Boost Views
Post's Text: Glorifying China—with a wink—is emerging as an unexpected new trend on TikTok, as users look for ways to boost audiences on the short video app whose already high popularity has soared during the pandemic.

Post's Title: Coronavirus This Week: Cases Surge in Several States Amid Reopenings
Post's Text: As confirmed coronavirus cases in the U.S. have topped 2.2 million, states have continued to push ahead with reopening.

Post's Title: Las Vegas Makes a Bet on Reopening Casinos Amid Coronavirus
Post's Text: Few American cities have been hit harder economically by the coronavirus lockdown than Las Vegas. WSJ visited the city’s famous strip to learn about how Sin City is reopening its casinos.

Post's Title: May’s U.S. Jobs Rebound Was Widespread
Post's Text: Nearly all U.S. states added jobs last month as business reopenings allowed most areas of the country to start recovering from huge employment losses endured earlier in the coronavirus pandemic.

Post's Title: As Covid-19 Hits Developing Countries, Its Victims Are Younger
Post's Text: As the coronavirus pandemic spreads from the hardest hit areas of Europe and the U.S. to the developing world, the age profile of its victims has changed: more middle-aged people are dying in poorer countries.

Post's Title: Village Life in India Won’t Be the Same as Coronavirus Chases Migrants Out of Cities
Post's Text: India’s villages, which have largely been spared from the coronavirus pandemic, now face the risk of local outbreaks and a plunge in revenue from remittances, as millions of jobless migrant workers return home.

Post's Title: Opinion | State Taxes Shouldn’t Be Another Pandemic Worry
Post's Text: From WSJ Opinion: Out-of-state medical workers who traveled to New York to help treat Covid-19 shouldn’t be stuck paying New York’s substantial income tax, writes Sen. John Thune.

Post's Title: Recent Protests May Not Be Covid-19 Transmission Hotspots
Post's Text: Early data suggest that recent protests against racial injustices haven't led to a marked uptick in new coronavirus cases. The data is still preliminary and officials warn protest-related cases could still rise.

Post's Title: Opinion | The Coming Urban Exodus
Post's Text: From WSJ Opinion: After months of the pandemic, protests and failing progressive leadership, many are going to move out of the U.S.’s urban centers, writes Dan Henninger.

Post's Title: China Tightens Controls Over Beijing as Coronavirus Infections Spread
Post's Text: Chinese officials canceled hundreds of flights in and out of Beijing, restricted movement and renewed closures of businesses and schools as they battled to contain a fresh wave of new coronavirus cases in the nation’s capital.

Post's Title: U.S. Experiencing Coin Shortage Due to Coronavirus Pandemic, Powell Says
Post's Text: The coronavirus pandemic has led to a shortage of coins in the U.S.

Post's Title: Dexamethasone Improves Survival in Severe Covid-19 Patients, Study Finds
Post's Text: A generic steroid drug is the first to show in a clinical trial it could improve the survival of severely ill coronavirus patients, University of Oxford researchers said.

Post's Title: U.S. Retail Sales Rose Record 18% in May
Post's Text: Renewed shopping drove a record 18% increase in retail sales in May, though total spending remained well below pre-coronavirus levels.

Post's Title: Expanded Tax Break for Charitable Gifts Gains Support in Congress
Post's Text: A bipartisan effort to expand tax breaks for charitable donations is gaining momentum in Congress, as nonprofit groups struggle during the pandemic.

Post's Title: Businesses to Slash Overseas Investment Amid Pandemic Risks
Post's Text: Firms are expected to slash new overseas investment in 2020 and 2021, hitting poorer countries hardest: "The first rungs on the development ladder could become much harder to climb."

Post's Title: Chinese Consumers Add Fuel to Factory-Led Economic Recovery
Post's Text: The encouraging indicators suggested to many economists that momentum around China’s coronavirus recovery is finally gathering a head of steam. Even so, it isn’t clear how long-lasting the rebound will be.

Post's Title: Opinion | New Rules for Covid Summer: Be Flexible and Vigilant
Post's Text: From WSJ Opinion: Public attitudes are now as mixed and contradictory as the epidemiology data. Officials need to focus on building confidence and minimizing weariness, write Scott Gottlieb and Yuval Levin.

Post's Title: Stocks Open Lower on Fears Over Fresh Virus Outbreaks
Post's Text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened about 600 points lower as investors worry fresh outbreaks of the coronavirus could hold back a global economic recovery.

Post's Title: Covid-19 Derails Retirement Plans of Older Small-Business Owners
Post's Text: “I’m sitting in my retirement,” says Dennis Dreibelbis, 69, whose small restaurant has been temporarily closed because of coronavirus.

Post's Text: Signal, the encrypted messaging app, is seeing record numbers of downloads amid the pandemic and nationwide protests.

Post's Text: Revenue collections are down world-wide. Tech companies are prospering. That combination is roiling international tax negotiations.
