Post's Title: Coronavirus Pressures Supply Chain for Protective Masks
Post's Text: A critical component in face masks that protect medical workers from the new coronavirus is highly sought after. “This has been unprecedented demand.”

Post's Title: Opinion | Coronavirus and the Tragedy of Iran
Post's Text: From WSJ Opinion: With a declining economy, a raging coronavirus epidemic, and an aged and ailing supreme leader, Iran in the coming years promises to be more interesting—and more dangerous—than at any time in recent memory, writes Robert D. Kaplan.

Post's Title: Global Medical Mystery: Can Classrooms Spread Coronavirus?
Post's Text: Confusion over what role children may play in spreading the disease has led officials to apply the strategy unevenly—catching parents and teachers by surprise and sowing confusion about whether schools are safe.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Checks Mean Confusion, Boredom on Cruise Ship Stuck off San Francisco
Post's Text: When the Grand Princess was diverted back to San Francisco to test dozens of people on board after a man on the cruise ship's previous voyage died from exposure, the announcement caught passengers and staff by surprise. “We were not given advance notice of this announcement by the federal government,” the cruise ship captain said in an address. “It would have been our preference to be the first to make this news available to you.”

Post's Title: Global Viral Outbreaks, Once Rare, Will Become More Common
Post's Text: Coronavirus making you nervous? Get used to it. “We’re going to get hit by a much bigger one sometime in the next 10 years,” says an epidemics expert.

Post's Title: Amazon Dogged by Price Gouging as Coronavirus Fears Grow
Post's Text: Amazon is struggling to stamp out third-party sellers charging exorbitant prices for virus-killing cleaning supplies, hand sanitizer and other products in high demand amid coronavirus fears.

Post's Title: How the Coronavirus Spread From One Patient to 1,000 Now Quarantined in New York
Post's Text: The case of a seriously ill father with roots in a modern Orthodox community shows how quickly coronavirus can spread where people live, go to school and attend services in a tight circle.

Post's Title: Watch: China Deploys Drones, Citizens and Big Data to Tackle Coronavirus
Post's Text: "Go home and wash your hands." "Please disperse now." "Don't go out and party."  Chinese authorities are deploying drones equipped with cameras and loudspeakers to scold citizens as part of their strategy to tackle the spread of the coronavirus.

Post's Title: High-Speed Trains, International Flights: How the Coronavirus Spread
Post's Text: China is far more mobile than it was during the SARS outbreak in 2003, giving new viruses a ready route to the world at large.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Spreads World-Wide, Containment Is an ‘Unlikely Outcome’
Post's Text: More coronavirus cases are reported globally, from Australia to South Korea, as officials warn it may be impossible to fully contain the pathogen.

Post's Title: Recruitment Begins for First Test of Experimental Coronavirus Vaccine
Post's Text: The trial vaccine contains the genetic material RNA, designed to instruct the human body’s cells to make a protein from the coronavirus that doesn’t cause infection but triggers an immune response to the virus. The vaccine isn’t made from the actual virus.

Post's Title: Six New Yorkers, Including Four Family Members, Have Coronavirus
Post's Text: The four family members are a 50-year-old attorney, his wife, their 14-year-old daughter, and their college-student son. A neighbor who had driven the attorney to the hospital had also tested positive, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said.

Post's Title: Curbed by Coronavirus, China’s Truckers Can’t Wait to Get on the Road Again
Post's Text: China has long relied on its 30 million-strong army of truck drivers. Now, the virus is keeping half of them off the road.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Spreads in Washington State as Amazon Worker Tests Positive
Post's Text: An Amazon employee in Seattle tests positive for the novel coronavirus, as concerns mount over the respiratory disease's spread in the U.S.

Post's Title: Drugmaker Takeda Is Working on Coronavirus Drug
Post's Text: Japanese company Takeda plans to develop a coronavirus drug derived from the blood of patients who have antibodies that helped them recover from infections.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Slams U.S. Hotel Industry’s Global Operations
Post's Text: The hotel industry’s decadelong run of growth and rising revenue looked vulnerable at the start of the year. Now the spread of the coronavirus threatens to make it the worst-performing year since the recession.

Post's Title: Coronavirus: You Ask, We Answer
Post's Text: "How do I know if I have coronavirus?" "How does the mortality rate of coronavirus compare with the flu?" "What are the 'underlying health conditions' that can put a person at greater risk of death from the coronavirus?" The Wall Street Journal has been taking questions from readers about the coronavirus. Here, we compile answers to your questions based on interviews with experts.

Post's Title: American Cycling Team Asks to Pull Out of Races in Italy Amid Coronavirus Concerns
Post's Text: An American cycling team asked to pull out of three major bike races in Italy this month, citing concerns about the novel coronavirus.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Prompts Poll Workers to Don Gloves, Offer Curbside Voting
Post's Text: "If you’re not wanting to be in a public space with a bunch of people, you can just stay in your car and flick the ballot out": The coronavirus outbreak collides with the presidential campaign.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Poses Dilemma for Workers Who Risk Losing Pay
Post's Text: Many sick U.S. workers face risk of losing pay, posing challenges amid coronavirus outbreak.

Post's Title: Canceled Games and Empty Stadiums: Will the Coronavirus Spread to Sports?
Post's Text: The busiest time of the American sports calendar is coming—if the coronavirus doesn’t come first.

Post's Title: Where’s the Hand Sanitizer? Coronavirus Fears Empty Store Shelves, Disrupt Plans
Post's Text: Despite the low risk of infection, Americans are taking steps to prepare for the possibility of serious outbreak as authorities urge calm.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Hits Once-Isolated U.S. Natural Gas Market
Post's Text: Fears that the coronavirus epidemic might slow the global economy have pushed already-depressed natural gas prices to their lowest level in years.

Post's Title: Global Growth to Slow Sharply as Coronavirus Takes Heavy Toll, Says OECD
Post's Text: The global economy will slow sharply this year as governments attempt to contain the coronavirus epidemic, although the scale of the setback is highly uncertain, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said. https://on.wsj.com/2TwOMEW

Post's Title: Coronavirus Spreading Faster Outside China Than Within
Post's Text: Coronavirus's global death toll surpasses 3,000, as new cases jump in Italy and South Korea and three more nations report their first confirmed patients.

Post's Title: Opinion | Trump Isn’t Easing Coronavirus Forebodings
Post's Text: From WSJ Opinion: If the coronavirus hits America hard, a lot will change—the national mood, cultural habits, the economy, writes Peggy Noonan.

Post's Title: Shrinking Profit Prospects Add to Threat for Stocks
Post's Text: There are few signs the economic fears prompted by the spreading coronavirus are about to subside.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Forces Families to Rip Up Spring Travel Plans
Post's Text: Many people are nixing travel and staying home, or grasping for alternate journeys that might feel safer.

Post's Title: U.K. Looks to Slow Coronavirus By a Different, Albeit Controversial, Way
Post's Text: Rather than ban mass gatherings and travel, the U.K. government is encouraging people to wash hands and stay home if they are sick.

Post's Title: Trump’s Coronavirus Risk Is Low Despite Potential Exposures, His Doctor Says
Post's Text: Three people who spent time last weekend at Mar-a-Lago have tested positive for the virus. The president is known to have interacted with two of them.

Post's Title: Strategic Partnership With China Lies at Root of Iran’s Coronavirus Outbreak
Post's Text: Iranian officials trace the origins of the country’s coronavirus epidemic to the holy city of Qom, home to dozens of seminaries and religious shrines—but also a number of Chinese-backed infrastructure projects built by scores of workers and technicians from China.

Post's Title: Watch: Coronavirus Strikes Officials Around the World. Are Governments Prepared?
Post's Text: Officials in several countries have tested positive for coronavirus, raising questions about world leaders' exposure to the pandemic. Here are some of the challenges governments face as they ponder contingency plans.

Post's Title: Augusta National Postpones the Masters
Post's Text: The Masters, the hallmark event of the golf calendar, has been postponed as the sports world effectively shuts down because of the coronavirus.

Post's Title: The Coronavirus and Your Job: What the Boss Can—and Can’t—Make You Do
Post's Text: Can my boss make me come to the office? Can my boss tell me to cancel my vacation? Employees have questions about coronavirus at work. We have answers.

Post's Title: Pandemic May Slow Delegate Elections for Presidential Nominating Conventions
Post's Text: The novel coronavirus pandemic is scrambling planning for this summer’s Democratic and Republican national conventions, but congressional district and state conventions are presenting an even more pressing problems.

Post's Title: FDA Grants New Coronavirus Test Emergency Approval
Post's Text: A high-speed coronavirus test developed by diagnostics giant Roche is granted emergency clearance by the Food and Drug Administratio.

Post's Title: Tightened Borders Re-Emerge in Fight Against Coronavirus Pandemic
Post's Text: The impact of these new travel and trade restrictions, along with a shortage of pharmaceutical components produced in China and other export curbs, is likely to outlast the pandemic itself, reshaping global trade flows and domestic politics in many democracies

Post's Title: Coronavirus-Driven Rate-Cutting Is Less Likely in Japan
Post's Text: How low can you go: The Fed, Bank of England and other central banks have cut rates to counteract coronavirus fears, but the Bank of Japan is already in negative territory https://on.wsj.com/2IInJl9

Post's Title: WSJ News Exclusive | Airbnb Bookings Plunge Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
Post's Text: “I survived guests stealing my car, guests burglarizing my home, guests with drug paraphernalia and even guests operating a suspected pop-up brothel. Coronavirus has been the worst and will force me to close.” Airbnb's bookings are tanking in major cities world-wide amid the coronavirus pandemic, new data show.

Post's Title: U.S. Hospitals Face Major Challenges as Coronavirus Spreads
Post's Text: “Duct tape solves a lot of problems”: U.S. hospitals are scrambling to prepare for the most-severe coronavirus cases.

Post's Title: As Coronavirus Spreads, Should You Have More Cash—or Less?
Post's Text: While some bank customers are nervous due to the coronavirus, experts advise that laundering cash isn’t necessary.

Post's Title: Broadway Goes Dark Due to Coronavirus Outbreak
Post's Text: New York's Broadway theaters will close as of 5 p.m. as the state bans gatherings of 500 people or more.

Post's Title: The Do’s and Don’ts of Handwashing
Post's Text: Handwashing is one of the best ways to avoid infection from the new coronavirus, but most people aren’t very good at it. Here’s expert guidance on how to do it right.

Post's Title: Italy Hardens Nationwide Quarantine
Post's Text: Italy ordered the nationwide closure of all restaurants and bars, along with most stores, as it raced to contain the coronavirus outbreak.

Post's Title: Tom Hanks and Wife, Rita Wilson, Test Positive for Coronavirus in Australia
Post's Text: Tom Hanks said he and Rita Wilson were in Australia preparing for a new film and started feeling ill.

Post's Title: HHS Secretary Is Largely Sidelined in U.S. Effort to Battle Coronavirus
Post's Text: After emerging early on as the White House’s public face in the battle against coronavirus and the head of a task force formed to wage it, Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar has since been noticeably absent.

Post's Title: How to Stock Up for Coronavirus Without Getting Fleeced
Post's Text: A guide to the best apps and websites for tracking down in-demand products like hand sanitizer and disinfectant wipes, and checking prices to avoid the gougers.

Post's Title: Airline Fees Rankle Travelers as Coronavirus Cancels Trips
Post's Text: Passengers want refunds, but airlines are often offering more limited alternatives.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Declared Pandemic by World Health Organization
Post's Text: China reports a rise in coronavirus infections imported from abroad as the number of cases in the U.S. tops 1,000.

Post's Title: Coronavirus vs. Flu: Which Virus is Deadlier?
Post's Text: The new coronavirus and the seasonal flu are both contagious respiratory diseases with similar symptoms, but so far the new malady appears to be deadlier.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Patient Recounts Coming ‘One Inch From Death’
Post's Text: “I’m 48 years old and I’m getting my last rites.” One of the first Americans diagnosed with the novel coronavirus speaks from the intensive-care unit about nearly losing his life.

Post's Title: Coronavirus Hurts Broadway Box Office
Post's Text: About half of Broadway shows are limiting contact at the stage door between cast members and the public to guard against the coronavirus.

Post's Title: Italy, With Aging Population, Has World’s Highest Daily Deaths From Virus
Post's Text: Italy’s high number of deaths from coronavirus has health experts worried. Many say that, if Italians are more likely to die, then demographics are probably a big part of the reason.

Post's Title: Trump to Propose Steps to Ease Economic Fallout From Coronavirus
Post's Text: President Trump is considering measures to ease the economic pain inflicted by the coronavirus, including a payroll-tax cut and help for hourly workers.

Post's Title: Opinion | How to Read the Myopic Market
Post's Text: From WSJ Opinion: The market is a coronavirus roller coaster because uncertainty can collapse the timeline on which investors predict growth and profits, writes Andy Kessler.

Post's Title: Number of Congressional Lawmakers in Self-Quarantine Due to Coronavirus Climbs to Five
Post's Text: The number of congressional lawmakers placing themselves into self-quarantine climbed to five on Monday, due to contacts with people who have tested positive for coronavirus infections.

Post's Title: N.Y. Port Authority Director Tests Positive for Coronavirus
Post's Text: Rick Cotton, the head of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, has tested positive for the coronavirus, according to New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

Post's Title: Stocks Fall More Than 7% in Dow’s Worst Day Since 2008
Post's Text: U.S. stocks careened on Monday, pushing major indexes closer to bear-market territory as a price war for oil and the fallout from the coronavirus frightened investors, who sought shelter in government bonds and propelled yields to unprecedented lows.

Post's Title: Health Agencies Tackle Coronavirus Epidemic With Dwindling Resources

Post's Title: Photos from The Wall Street Journal's post
Post's Text: In Tuskegee, Ala., history is driving distrust in Covid-19 vaccines for many Black residents.   Beginning in the 1930s, federal officials enrolled hundreds of Black men in Tuskegee in an experiment to examine the effects of untreated syphilis. The men were told they were being treated for “bad blood,” according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In fact, the infected were left to suffer and die from syphilis, decades after treatment existed.  Black residents say the pain and distrust fomented by this study are inseparable from their personal deliberations over whether to take a Covid-19 vaccine.  At Tuskegee’s farmers market on a recent morning, David Banks said he won’t get the shot because he doesn’t trust those administering it. The 67-year-old said some neighbors have said they suspect the first dose of a two-shot regimen is used to infect a person, and the second to see if they are cured.  “It’s cynical,” he said. “But like I said, they have reason to be.”  Read more: https://on.wsj.com/3kqvwpP  Photos by Lynsey Weatherspoon for WSJ

Post's Text: Pastors like the Rev. Miniard Culpepper are emerging as local influencers in America’s sprawling Covid-19 vaccination ground game.  Culpepper, of Boston’s Pleasant Hill Missionary Baptist, and other Black clergy are trying to counter the hesitancy of many Black adults who may avoid the vaccine over safety worries and mistrust of the medical field.   Black and Latino Americans have died of the coronavirus at more than twice the rate of white residents, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.  “This new strain, Lord have mercy,” Culpepper preached on a recent Sunday to the small, socially distanced congregation and some 200 worshipers watching remotely. “Pray that even with this new strain, that as folks get vaccinated—and we pray that folks do get vaccinated—that we’ll see the numbers come down.”  One-third of Black adults say they plan to avoid the Covid-19 shots, compared with about one-fifth of Hispanic and white adults who don’t plan to get vaccinated, according to recent survey data from the U.S. Census Bureau.   “We christen their babies, we do their funerals, do their marriages, do prayer for them, and are at the hospital with them,” said Culpepper. “I don’t think there is anything my church won’t come to me with.”⠀  Read more: https://on.wsj.com/3dIxWyE  Photos by Kayana Szymczak for WSJ

Post's Title: Photos from The Wall Street Journal's post
Post's Text: Nearly a year after some spring breakers in Miami Beach refused to let the coronavirus interrupt their parties and helped trigger a wave of lockdowns, this city is bracing for a fresh crop of revelers.  Though many colleges have canceled spring break to prevent students from congregating in vacation spots, officials here are expecting a large influx over the coming weeks. Flights and hotels are cheap. Brutal winter storms in much of the country left people yearning for an escape. And Florida’s pandemic rules on bars and nightclubs are more lenient than those in many states.  “We could potentially see a truly outsized spring break at a time when the last thing we want are major gatherings,” said Miami Beach Mayor Dan Gelber, a Democrat. He cited public-health specialists’ concerns that such crowds could generate another surge of Covid-19 cases.  Read more: https://on.wsj.com/3sJPIWw  Photos by Maria Alejandra Cardona for WSJ

Post's Title: U.S. Farmers Vie For The Hottest Commodity Around: Land
Post's Text: Across the Midwest, prices to buy and rent farmland are climbing as demand is driven by rallying grain markets, historic government payments and low interest rates, according to economists, agricultural lenders and land managers.⁠  The battle for farmland is playing out in small town community centers, online portals and parking lots, where bids in Covid-19-era auctions are placed. There, auctioneers are peddling parcels of land to farmers eager to cash in on the best commodity prices in nearly a decade. They are also presiding over intense jockeying for fields that can test the fabric of rural communities as a shrinking set of growers compete for control of the nation’s prime soil.⁠  Farmland managers say more people are vying for land, and that some parcels are selling at—or above—prices seen during the previous farm boom nearly a decade ago. Farmland values rose during 2020 as soaring grain prices last fall revived farmers’ fortunes, according to February reports from three regional Federal Reserve Banks. Many agricultural lenders surveyed by the banks expected farmland values to rise this year as well.⁠  Kansas farmer Cole Carpenter, shown in the clip here, says he works hard to hang onto the land he leases, recently investing in technology to provide landowners with real-time, personalized data on how many bushels he harvested or acres he sprayed with fertilizer in a given wheat field. Still, he fears his ground will be the next target of a large farmer in his area, who is quickly amassing acreage.⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ “The big are getting bigger, and the rest of us are trying to hold our own,” he said.⁠  Read more: https://on.wsj.com/3fyyPe7  Video: Katie Klann for WSJ

Post's Title: Photos from The Wall Street Journal's post
Post's Text: Brazil is in the throes of a battle against the new Covid-19 variant from the Amazon that threatens to send shock waves across the globe.  Home to less than 3% of the world’s population, the country currently accounts for almost a third of the daily global deaths from Covid-19, driven by the new variant. More than 300,000 have died, and daily deaths now top 3,000, a toll suffered only by the far more populous U.S.⠀  “We’re in the trenches here, fighting a war,” said Andréia Cruz, a 42-year-old emergency-ward nurse in the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre. In the past three weeks alone, the surrounding state of Rio Grande do Sul has seen nearly 5,000 people die from Covid-19, more than in the final three months of last year.  The spread of the virus in Brazil threatens to turn the country of 213 million into a global public-health hazard. The so-called P.1 strain, present in more than 20 countries and recently identified in New York, is up to 2.2 times more contagious and as much as 61% more able to reinfect people than previous versions of the coronavirus, according to a recent study.  The P.1 is now responsible for the majority of new infections in Brazil, with many doctors here saying they are seeing more young and otherwise healthy patients falling ill. About 30% of people dying from Covid-19 are now under 60, compared with an average of about 26% during Brazil’s previous peak between June and August, according to official figures analyzed by The Wall Street Journal.⠀ ⠀ Read more: https://on.wsj.com/39zcitK ⠀ Photos: Tom Protti for WSJ

Post's Text: Catholics might be somewhat confused by reports on differing messages about the acceptability of the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine. The differences have now been resolved.

Post's Title: Pregnant women 'didn't have the data' – until now: COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective, even for babies, study shows
Post's Text: According to a new study, COVID-19 vaccines are effective at protecting pregnant women and likely provide protection for their babies as well.  Earlier studies suggested the COVID-19 vaccines from Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna would be safe and effective. But this is the largest study to date looking at the immune responses of pregnant and lactating women to vaccination.

Post's Text: The theory that the coronavirus pandemic originated from a Chinese lab drew little support from a joint World Health Organization-China study on the origins of the global crisis that has claimed almost 2.8 million lives.  The report released Tuesday backs the previously accepted theory that the virus was most likely transmitted from bats to humans through another animal.
